title: Big Data Public Private Forum (BIG) initiative

author: Nuria de Lama Sanchez, ATOS Worldline

segmentation: Good afternoon to all of you.
My name is newly alama, an IAM representative photos research and innovation to the European Commission.
My presentation will be a bit different to what you have heard so far, but I think it will be funny or at least provocative.
Just closing the conference or close to the end of the conference.
So mainly I will present a project that has not started yet.
I don't know if that is a challenge or not because people are more interested in getting results of things that have already been done.
The good thing is that since the project has not started yet is an open opportunity for all of you to get involved in that because that's what we want.
And in fact, I really thank detailed to give me this lot.

I know I have to pay for that, but I really think that I should use this opportunity to make you know this project and try to get your attention in order that you contribute to everything that we are going to do in the coming years.
So my presentation will be based on three things.

I must recognize that I changed it just at the last moment because I thought there was one specific thing that was not fitting very well, and after listening to all these presentations, I think it could fit well.
So I decided to change it.
First of all, I will tell you about the motivation for this proposal.
Second, I will let you know about a possible example that we do take.
We could take into account as learning experience for the work we are going to do here.
That is the PPP on future Internet set up by another area of the European Commission.
And finally I will let you know about the project began, what we plan to do there.
So in terms of motivation, I have taken only an example of my company at us for you to know more or less the kind of needs we have at this very moment, I.

I don't know if you are aware that this is the ideal partner for the Olympic Games, so that managed that means that we manage all the technology that has to do with the Olympic Games since Barcelona and what you can see here, the kind of figures we are managing at this very moment in London.
But this will increase even in Rio, which is a contract that was also awarded to our company and you can see that for example we will process 2 million visitors.
That means 30% more than what we got in Beijing.
So I will not go figure after figure here.

But you can get a glimpse of the kind of information we are managing at this very moment, which means a lot of problems in terms of gathering data, analyzing data, but not only from the technical point of view.
It's also a talent in terms of finding new applications that could be more innovative for the users.

So in that respect, what we try to provide in the project is not only the technical solutions to manage analyzers, store data, this kind of things, but also try to foster the use of data to create more innovative.
Services and applications.
So this is only an example and others like that.
I like to use because I think that it's also a very good example.
Is that this analysis made by IBM about what could be the future of the telecom sector.
So what you can see here is 4 scenarios with four different hypothesis based on the degree of openness of the companies involving this sector.
So for example you can see on the down left part the survival consolidation.
This means that can Co operators.
Will not open the resources and they will stay as they did in the past, so they will retain their business models.
They will retain all their resources and they will not collaborate with anyone you can see also the class of Giants scenario.
This means that telecom operators will open a bit to some big industries, for example in vertical sectors like health or smart energy.
So they will try to find new markets providing their services to be customers in other sectors.
The market shakeout which is under scenario consisting on.
Open innovate the kind of functionality is they are doing and let other people provide the same services.
For example, city halls are providing now broadband services to their citizens, so that's a way of opening a bit the market.
Finally, the generative Bazaar, which is an scenario consisting on opening almost everything that you put the resources available for any kind of 3rd party that wants to make use of that.
So the interesting thing is not the definition of this forest scenarios, but the possible result.
In terms of business that could be generate.
It here so as I said before, this is an analysis performed as IBM, but I only wanted to use it as an example and what you can see there is that precisely this scenario.

Generative bizarre is the one that would create more business around so, and is precisely the one consisting on not protecting all your resources, but opening everything, maybe providing APIs and let other companies, individuals, big and small companies provide other applications and services on top of all the technology and the resources you already have.

So this shows the potential in terms of business of openness and collaboration with other companies, and I think that maybe we could take it as an example because I think it can be translated to many other sectors, including the one we are talking about of course.
So all these things are a good introduction to let you know about one initiative that was an example when we decided to submit this proposal, and.
Is the future Internet dipping?
I will be brief because many of you may not be interested in this.
But as I said before, I want to show some how the picture that motivated the submission of this proposal.

As you know, at this moment the Commission has a program called FP 7 which is more focused on long-term research and also the CI P that is more focused on deploying and validating services and applications.
Well, this PPP is in the middle of the two of them, so it's an initiative fostering innovation, doing some research, but closer to the market.
And one of the important things is that all the things that will be developed here should be adapted to the demand, which is something that not all the projects in FP7 have followed so far.
And it is one of the key issues of our.
Pro yet being adapted to the demands and to the possible needs of the customers, so the result of the conception of these PPP was a program in which the Commission has funded several projects.
One of them is the so called firework, which is the technology foundation of the PPP and is a very big technical project providing a lot of technologies.
And apart from that there are eight use cases.
Use cases are projects that are focused on one specific sector.
So for example, we have logistics.
We have transport.
We have environment.
They say security, smart cities all kind of sectors that you could imagine.
The important thing of the program is that all these projects have to work together, even if they have their contract somehow.

This contract is flexible enough to allow all of them change a bit what they are doing, and this file where this technological project should provide the technology that is in the contract but also should be able to adapt to the needs of all these sectors.
So the important thing is that this should not be technology that in the end will be in a research institution or University without any use.
But should be really used by companies in the diff.

Insektors so this file were project that I have mentioned is a very big one with 26 partners, a total funding, a 41 million euro and with some open calls where you may participate by the way and a total value of more than 60 million euros.
So as you can see, it's a very big one, is coordinated by Telefonica and all the major items until companies in Europe are involved.

And as I said before, the important thing is that fine word doesn't work for itself, only for the purpose of creating technology, but tries to take into account the requirements and the needs of all these sectors that are projects themselves.
So find what he's focused on many technological areas.
As you can imagine, including services cloud, Internet or thin support Services Internet interface to the network and devices security and the provision of tools for developers.
I will not go into the detail, but at least like that you can go.
That website afterwards, if you want to get more information about that one of these chapters is also including some developments about big data and data analysis in general.
So important also to see that other people and other companies are doing things that are quite similar to the things that you have explained in the previous presentations.
And I could also be a link to collaborate with them.
And the ones that I have explained this only as a motivation and introduction.
I would like to let you know the kind of project that we have proposed that we are still in the negative.

Asian face some of these things may not be completely updated, but at least the key facts of the project is at this coordination action of two years of duration with eleven partners at this very moment it may be 12 and around 3 million euro budget.

As you can see, the control team is composed of very different partners where we have tried to compile excellent people in the academic environment, but one of the very important things of this proposal is that we wanted to attract big industries, and as you can see there we have.
After we have British Telecom, we have Simmons.
Also, some SM is an representative associations like the Open Knowledge Foundation or Press Association.
So the important thing is that we have tried to cover all the profiles that could be needed.

A seat for this initiative, which is the overall objective of the project, mainly to address technical, business and policy aspects in intelligent information management and big data with several links.
First of all, shaping the future of the area.
Put in this area in the right position.
From the political point of view and also contributing to the competitiveness of European industries.
Having a kind of industry that is well established in Europe where all the companies can collaborate together.
So the main mission is not only technical, but we are really thinking about tackling all the issues that could prevent big data.
In general data technologies from being exploited in the right way for this.
As I said before, we need to work with academia, but it is really important that we attract industrial partners in order to succeed in this.
So one of the important things is that we talk a lot about the future technologies.
What could we could develop in the future, but one of the things we want to do in this project is to promote the adoption.
Technology that is already out there, so I'm not waiting all the time until 2020 when we have more development but saying OK, we have a lot of technologies available.
Now let's try to promote what is already there.
Let's have pilots, unless you use what we already have and this doesn't prevent us from already defining what the future should be based on the needs of these customers.
So they complete objectives of the project are mainly to define stakeholders on the players that should be involved, to have a clear picture of all the technology trends.
So have a kind of state of the art.
With a very clear information about the maturity of the different technologies, because sometimes it seems that things are ready, and when you really go to an operational environment, nothing works.
So I think it's very important also that we have this kind of perspective of what can be used in the market and what should already be part of the research of the future.
Have also a sharp understanding and this is the important thing of how big data could be applied to these different sectors.
So again, we are focusing very much on the adoption and the use of the technologies.
Disseminate resource and of course involves stakeholders because we don't want to be the only ones doing this.
In that case, it will not be valid defined the priorities based on the expected impact on this.
We are not doing research only because it's nice.

It's interesting, but because this will really have an impact on the industries, the competitiveness either cause or a more innovative services and applications and size it before contributing general to the future of Europe thanks to the.
So we are not only doing technical things which will be covered, but will also tackle policy, regulation and business aspects that are needed in order to succeed.
We will not only discuss generic plans for research in the future, but we will really try to have specific plans for adoption.

We will not promise things only after the project completion, but we try to do things already during the project execution in terms of actions that show the way we are promoting this adoption of the technology.
And finally, one important thing is that we have committed to have a kind of forum.
These are big data public private forum as we have call it so far.
That will go beyond the project duration, so we have initiated this because we believe in that and we want this to be a long term initiative and not only a project of 24 months.
This is only the starting point of what we want to do.

More or less the approach of the project is that we think also that there are a lot of valuable European projects that have a lot of things, but in general not all these messages reach the right political level.
So and at the same time the right the political level doesn't reach.
Also, sometimes in terms of the priorities to the projects, so we will really try to make this channel a bit wider to have further communication.
And for you to have an idea of the major activities of the project, here you have an schema that represents quite well what we plan to do.
We will have this technology state of the art and sector analysis that will focus on both the technologies but also the sectors or application domains.
Based on that we will have a Rd mapping activity that will try to put the different things in common.
The good thing is that we will provide Rd Maps for each of the sectors plus an integrated road map that will take into account the needs and the requirements from a general.
Point of view and finally taking into account all these, we will set up this big data public private forum trying to get all the stakeholders that are needed on board.
So of course you are.
If I do that, I will not go into the details, but this is the methodology we will follow to do this work.
As you can see, we will try to answer many questions related to many things that we think that are necessary.

In this context and for you to have an idea about the specific context contents we have defined so far, this is what appears in the description of work at this very moment, But if any of you has a more innovative ideas, I'm going to contribute to this.
We are more than open in principle we will tackle data acquisition, data analysis, data curation.

I think this is very important because of data provenance, trust data validation are aspects that have not been tackled so much in the conference today, and they are really important in terms of using data.
Data storage and data usage OK.

These are some of the things we will tackle from the technical point of view, but as I said before, we will have working groups addressing specifically the needs and the requirements from the health domain, public sector finance and insurance tell comedian, entertainment, manufacturing, retail energy and transport.
So the idea in the end is to align the supply and the demand.
And this is my last slide.
This is my contact information.
If you are interested in getting on board, give me a call or send an email to me.
Many of the partners of the consortium are also here so you can contact any of us.

Thank you very much for this opportunity and if you are interested I would really like to ask you already to provide your business cards to me and I will have some Contacts already when I come back to Madrid to analyze the possible companies that are interested.
You will get in formation quite soon.
As I said before, the project has not started.
Probably Steven or will also disseminate what we are doing.
And as soon as the website is up and running, we will know about all the initiatives we are doing.
But both of you are users.
If you are research organizations.
If you are industries that are working from a research point of view in these aspects, or if you really want to get informed to provide your vision on this, come to us.
So thank you very much.
I cannot use my privilege.
I would like to offer a layer of comments on top of what Luria said.

So there is a principle called the conways rule of the organizational homeomorphism and it basically means that if your organization has it polka dots Department and the Wheels Department and it's been asked to design a boat you will end up with a boat that has.
Videos and polka dots.
OK so that May or may not be the optimal design for above, so transfer this notion to the particular project you are embarking on.
So and ask yourself if we're going to have as part of this initiative in polka.co and a wheels company and we have to design the future that data future of Europe.
Is it going to be a future with wheels and polka dots?

If perhaps they don't need to be there, So what I'm trying to say is that it is important that in this kind of initiative there should be a level of abstraction and trends analysis that transcends the linear interpolation of what everybody is doing today into a future that drives five years out.
Thank you very much for the comment.
